Stock futures continued to slip lower ahead of Wednesday's open as earnings reports weighed to the downside.
Dow futures dropped 20 points. Nasdaq 100 futures traded down 5.3 points and S&P 500 futures were off 2.8 points.

Action in overseas markets was mild as uncertainty over the staying power of the Greek debt deal and bailout accord dragged on trade. Asia's markets closed slightly higher. Europe's markets traded fractionally lower after a purchasing manager's index showed the euro zone's service sector slipping from mild expansion to mild contraction in February.

Gold dipped slightly to below $1,755 an ounce. Oil prices were off a few cents, holding just below $106 a barrel. Oil closed at $105.84 Tuesday, up 9% since Feb. 2 and at its highest close in nine months. Uncertainty over oil supplies out of Iran appear to have driven the gains.

In stocks, global positioning system device maker Garmin (GRMN) shot up 12% in premarket action. The company pounded analyst expectations, citing a rise in personal navigation system device sales for the first time in several quarters. Q4 EPS were 96 cents, up 16%. Analysts had expected 65 cents. A 9% gain in revenue to $910 million also easily beat views. The company lifted both earnings and revenue guidance above forecasts.

High-end home builder Toll Brothers (TOL) pared losses and was down 3% ahead of the open. Weak first quarter home deliveries dragged Q4 results to a loss of two cents per share vs. views for a two-cent gain. Revenue slipped 4% to $322 million, below forecasts for $360.8 million. Home deliveries slipped 1% year-over-year, and the company's customer cancellation rate increased to 6.2%, vs. 5.7% a year ago.

Chief Executive Douglas Yearley, Jr. said typically, the first quarter is the most challenging time to gauge home buyer sentiment, but, in general, "the market feels healthier than it did one year ago."

Dell (DELL) dropped 7% in premarket trade after reporting late Tuesday its Q4 earnings fell 4% to 51 cents - a penny below views. A 2% gain in revenue to $16.03 billion cleared forecasts, but the company's Q1 revenue guidance didn't. Citigroup and Needham downgraded the stock to neutral and hold, from buy.

The session is in some ways overshadowed by a busy schedule of after-hours earnings reports. Hewlett Packard (HPQ), Concho Resources (CXO), Williams Co.WMB, Analog Devices (ADI) and Sturm Ruger (RGR) are among the companies slated to report.Stock futures continued to slip lower ahead of Wednesday's open as earnings reports weighed to the downside.Dow futures dropped 20 points. Nasdaq 100 futures traded down 5.3 points and S&P 500 futures were off 2.8 points.Action in overseas markets was mild as uncertainty over the staying power of the Greek debt deal and bailout accord dragged on trade. Asia's markets closed slightly higher. Europe's markets traded fractionally lower after a purchasing manager's index showed the euro zone's service sector slipping from mild expansion to mild contraction in February.Gold dipped slightly to below $1,755 an ounce. Oil prices were off a few cents, holding just below $106 a barrel. Oil closed at $105.84 Tuesday, up 9% since Feb. 2 and at its highest close in nine months. Stock futures were off their best levels Wednesday, but still signaled a higher open as the market looks to bounce back from Tuesday's beating.
Nasdaq 100 futures rallied 6 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures climbed 2 points and Dow futures rose 13 points.
Oil extended Tuesday's 6% gain. The April contract added 54 cents to $95.96 a barrel on fears that unrest in Libya would spread. Gold, which is seen as a safe haven, rose $3.70 to $1,404.80 an ounce.

In corporate news, Nordson (NDSN) shares were indicated sharply higher after its stellar quarterly results late Tuesday. The maker of adhesive dispensing systems reported an 86% gain in fiscal Q1 earnings and a 23% increase in sales. Nordson cleared a 95.92 buy point in a square-box base Feb. 2.

Herbalife (HLF) rose 9% in the pre-open after beating views late Tuesday. The nutritional supplement's firm Q4 earning grew 34%, while sales rose 17%. Herbalife raised is full-year 2011 profit outlook to a range of $5.15 to $5.40 a share vs. views of $5.28.

The Fresh Market (TFM) lost 4% in pre-open trading despite topping views. The supermarket operator reported Q4 earnings of 33 cents a share, up from 27 cents a share earlier and 3 cents above estimates. Sales rose 13%, also beating views. The Fresh Market pegged full-year 2011 profit of $1.01 to $1.05 a share vs. views of $1.01. The stock on Friday cleared a 44.72 buy point from a cup base.

Netflix (NFLX) fell 2% in pre-market trading after being downgraded. Needham Research cut the DVD rental company to underperform from hold, saying that Amazon.com's (AMZN) streaming service, announced Tuesday, could hurt Netflix's growth. Netflix has now erased a chunk of gains after clearing a 209.34 buy point from a later-stage pattern Jan. 27.
Data on January existing home sales will be out at 10 a.m. EST. Economists see sales slipping to an annualized rate of 5.23 million units from 5.28 million units in December.

The major indexes held moderate losses in late trading Tuesday.The NYSE composite dropped 0.8%, the S&P 500 0.6% and the Nasdaq 0.6%. Volume was up 4% on the Nasdaq and 16% on the NYSE compared with the same time yesterday.Some 80% of industries tracked by IBD were down for the day, with techs continuing to take hits. The Philadelphia semiconductor index was down 1.5% but remains up 5.8% so far this year.Nvidia (NVDA) fell 3%, though it remained near a 52-week high. SanDisk (SNDK) gave up more than 4% and touched its 50-day moving average.Two oil and gas exploration and production plays, Concho Resources (CXO) and Northern Oil & Gas (NOG), booked losses. Northern Oil fell 4% in strong trade, slicing through its 10-week moving average for the first time since August. Concho also fell 4%, but in moderate trade. The stock was performing the latest of several pullbacks to the 10-week line over the past many months.Skyworks Solutions  (SWKS) climbed 2% in strong trade. The maker of chips used in mobile phones topped fourth-quarter expectations Jan. 20. Shares initially plunged 11% after the report before bouncing off 10-week support. Skyworks is still 10% below its Jan. 19 high.Another tech leader, Acme Packet (APKT), fell 4% in heavy trade. Acme, which makes products that interconnect networks, was caught in the Jan. 19 tech sell-off. The stock tumbled 12% last week. This week it's dropped 8%, slicing its 50-day line. Shares are back to early-December levels. Analysts see a 100% jump in earnings and a 46% sales gain when the company reports its fourth-quarter results next Tuesday.

Unlike recent sessions, tech stocks failed to grab the spotlight. Digital entertainment software developer Rovi (ROVI) fell 1%, staging a downside reversing from its morning gains. But the day's loss and volume pale in comparison to the dramatic surge seen Monday.

One tech stock that stood out Tuesday was Interactive Intelligence (ININ), a maker of call-center software. The thinly traded stock gapped up and soared 24% in monster trade. The market embraced the company's preliminary fourth-quarter results, released late Monday.

But Tuesday belonged to commodity stocks. Oil & gas, coal, steel, mining and farm-equipment makers dominated the day's best-performing groups. Gold miners enjoyed some relief from recent losses as bullion prices rebounded slightly. Crude oil surged $2 a barrel, bringing its two-day win tally to $3.23, thanks to the Alaska supply disruption. Natural gas, silver and copper also rose.

Continental Resources (CLR), a U.S. oil producer, shot up 5% in more than twice its usual trade. Concho Resources (CXO), another from that high-ranked group, gapped up and rose 2%. But, despite the gain, Concho staged a downside reversal by closing in the lower end of the day's trading range.

Wednesday's economic calendar will include the Mortgage Bankers Association's purchase applications, the Labor Department's December import and export prices and the Fed's beige book, a regional look at economic conditions.

The major indexes continued to trade moderately lower Wednesday, following the release of an ugly reading on new home sales.
The Nasdaq fell 0.6%, the S&P 500 and NYSE composite 0.5% each, and the Dow 0.3%. Volume swelled 20% on the NYSE and 16% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Tuesday.

New home sales plummeted 32.7%, the largest recorded drop in history, easily surpassing the 23.8% decline from January 1994. Regionally, sales dived 53.2% in the West, 25.4% in the South, 23.9% in the Midwest and 33.3% in the Northeast.

But even if tight trade doesn't lead to a three-weeks-tight, it's still a favorable development. It's not a bad idea to be ready before a three-weeks-tight pattern is complete. If the stock breaks out, you don't want to be caught reading…

Oil may have been sucked out of the Permian Basin in West Texas for nearly a century, but operators are still trying to strike it rich in what remains one of the top oil and gas fields in the U.S. Activity has been perking in the mature basin thanks to new technology, robust oil prices and availability of investment capital.…

Thursday earnings: Latin American e-commerce powerhouse MercadoLibre said after the close that it earned 47 cents a share up 31% vs a year earlier but 4 cents below analyst forecasts. Revenue rose 39% to $86.5 million, slightly below forecasts. MercadoLibre raised its quarterly dividend by 36% to 10.9 cents a share. But shares tumbled 6% in early after hours trading. They sank 0.7% to 97 in Thursday's regular session.But shortly after Friday's market open, MercadoLibre were up more than 4% to 101.26, back at record highs. Analysts noted foreign exchange swings hurt results, but stressed that underlying growth is strong.Monster Beverage earned 35 cents a share, up 32% vs. a split-adjusted 26.5 cents a year earlier but a penny below Wall Street estimates. Sales grew 29% to $410 million, just below views of $410 million. Shares of the energy drink maker fell 5% in early after-hours trading, reversed to move 2% higher, before moving slightly lower. The stock fell 19 cents to 54.87 in the regular session.But shortly after the market open, Monster Beverage shares were up 3% to 56.45. UBS raised its price target to $65 from $62.50, citing international growth and other opportunities for gains.***Wednesday earnings: Discounters Dollar Tree and TJX Cos. report before Wednesday's opening bell, continuing the week's run of major and often top-performing retailers.Specialty discounter Dollar Tree reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter profit and sales, but gave somewhat cautious guidance for the current first quarter. The company's earnings per share rose 24% to $1.60. Revenue climbed 13% to $1.95 billion. Analysts expected EPS of $1.58 on sales of $1.93 billion. Same-store sales increased 7.3% while store square footage rose 6.9% vs. a year earlier. Operating margins rose on higher gross margins and lower operating costs.For Q1 Dollar Tree expects to earn 91-97 cents a share on revenue of $1.65 billion-$1.69 billion. That assumes low- to mid-single-digit same-store sales growth. But it's slightly below Wall Street forecasts for EPS of 98 cents and revenue of nearly $1.70 billion.Dollar Tree shares fell 0.7% on Wednesday, off from session lows. The stock hit a new high intraday Tuesday, but closed down 1.5%TJX Cos. reported a 17% EPS gain to 62 cents as revenue rose 6% to $6.71 billion. Analysts expected a 62-cent gain and sales of $6.725 billion. Same-store sales rose 7%. TJX's Q1 EPS forecast for 45-47 cents is in line with Wall Street forecasts. That assumes 2%-4% same-store sales growth.The retailer hiked its quarterly dividend by 21% to 11.5 cents a share.TJX shares closed down 0.3%.After Wednesday's close, highly rated Limited Brands reported Q4 results, but the Victoria's Secret parent's Q1 guidance sent shares lower in late trading. But Limited  was fractionally higher Thursday afternoon.Also after Wednesday's close, IBD 50's Concho Resources and Questcor Pharmaceuticals reported results. Questcor reported adjusted Q4 EPS of 47 cents, up 292%, on revenue of $75.5 million, up 158%. That beat Wall Street views for EPS of 42 cents and  revenue of $72.8 million. Shares shot up 8% in Thursday afternoon trading.Concho earned $1.15 a share adjusted, up 53% vs. a year earlier but

missing views for $1.19. Revenue rose 48% to $478.4 million, above views for $451.79 million. Shares fell more than 5% in Thursday afternoon trading.***Tuesday update: Steven Madden kicked off IBD 50 earnings results Tuesday morning, reporting earnings per share of 55 cents, up 34% vs. a year earlier and 1 cent above analyst estimates. Revenue shot up 74% to $279.8 million, as its larger wholesale business to other retailers nearly doubled. Sales at its retail operations rose nearly 19% to $53.8 million, with same-store sales up 15.9%.The shoe and accessories designer, wholesaler and retailer said earnings sees this year's profit of $2.60-$2.70 vs. analyst views of $2.69 million. It sees revenue climbing 21%-23%, or roughly $1.18 billion, vs. the consensus of about $1.20 billion.Steven Madden shares fell 2.4% to 42.20.After Tuesday's close, Herbalife reported earnings per share of 86 cents, up 30% vs. a year earlier and 13 cents above Wall Street forecasts. Revenue jumped 20% to $884.6 mil, significantly above analyst estimates. Asian and Latin American growth led the way.The direct seller of nutritional products sees Q1 EPS of 76-80 cents and raised its full-year 2012 EPS target to $3.40-$3.60. Both bracket Wall Street estimates.The company also raised its quarterly dividend to 30 cents a share from 20 cents.Herbalife shares rose nearly 6% in early after-hours trading. During the regular session, the stock climbed about 3% to 62.46, breaking out of a recent consolidation.Herbalife holds a post-earnings conference call on Wednesday morning.*** Posted 2/18/2012 10:05 AM ETEarnings season may be winding down, but not for leading stocks. At least eight companies from the IBD 50 list report quarterly results this week. Most are consumer-related.Tuesday, Feb. 21Herbalife (HLF)Herbalife sells nutritional products worldwide via a massive direct sales force. Asia accounts for most of its growth.Fourth-quarter earnings likely rose 11% to 73 cents a share, analysts say. Sales probably rose 16% to $856.6 million.Shares are near the top of a consolidation going back to early August.Steven Madden (SHOO)The fashion and accessories shoe designer, marketer and retailer should turn out a blowout Q4. Analysts see earnings climbing 32% to 54 cents a share. They expect sales to jump 65.3% to $266.20 million. That would be the ninth quarter in a row of double-digit sales and profit growth.Madden markets products under its own brands, such as Steve Madden and Betsey Johnson.Steven Madden has 84 retail stores, but its wholesale business is much larger. It distributes its products to various retailers, including department stores and specialty chains.Steven Madden shares hit a new high last week.Madden is one of 12 major retailers reporting earnings this week — including the very biggest. Two other IBD 50 retailers report on Wednesday.Wednesday, Feb. 22Concho Resources (CXO)Concho is a domestic energy producer, specializing in the Permian Basin straddling Texas and New Mexico. In Q3, oil accounted for 73% of sales and natural gas 27%.Analysts expect Concho to report a 59% earnings per share gain to $1.19. Revenue likely rose 40% to $451.8 million.With oil prices rising above $100 a barrel last week, Concho shares hit a new high intraday on Friday.Dollar Tree (DLTR)Analysts see its earnings rising 22.5% vs. a year ago to $1.58 a share. They forecast a 12% sales gain to $1.9 billion. That would be Dollar Tree's 12th straight quarter of double-digit sales and profit growth.The specialty discounter sells everything for $1 or less. But its shares are up 547% from the January 2008 low, hitting a fresh high on Friday.Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR)The drugmaker pre-announced on Feb. 3 that H.P. Acthar Gel sales were $75 million in Q4. Questcor also said it expects to report operating income of $41 million to $43 million. Both were better than analysts expected.Shares popped on that day, but then resumed their decline from their Dec. 9 record high. The stock is approaching its 200-day moving average.TJX Cos. (TJX)The owner of the T.J. Maxx, Marshalls and Home Goods chains offers brand-name products at discounts of 20%-60%. Analysts expect TJX Cos. to report a 17% EPS gain to 62 cents. Sales likely grew 11% to $6.72 billion.TJX shares have been steadily climbing for months, rising 2% on Friday to a new high.In addition to Dollar Tree and TJX, highly rated (but not-quite IBD 50) Limited Brands (LTD) reports earnings Wednesday. It operates the Victoria's Secret and Bath & Body Works chains.Thursday, Feb. 23MercadoLibre (MELI)The Argentina-based Internet firm often is called "Latin America's eBay (EBAY)." The company offers a buying and selling platform in Argentina, Brazil, Mexico and more. Internet use in the region is surging from low levels.Analysts see MercadoLibre reporting a 42% EPS gain, with Q4 revenue up 41% to $87.7 million.Shares broke out to a new high on Wednesday, but pulled back the next two sessions.Monster Beverage (MNST)Formerly known as Hansen Natural, the beverage maker changed its name to reflect the importance of its caffeine-spiked energy drink, which is 90% of total sales. Natural sodas, juices and iced teas make up the rest.The U.S. energy drink market remains strong in the U.S., and Monster keeps pushing into more parts of Europe. Its main rival is Red Bull.Monster's Q4 earnings rose 33% to 36 cents a share, analysts predict. Revenue likely climbed 29% to $411 million.Follow Ed Carson on Twitter: @EdCarson1.

On March 12, 2009, the S&P 500 and NYSE composite delivered a follow-through day, confirming a market uptrend was under way.
With hindsight, we know this was a great time to buy stocks. But how could an investor have known which stocks were best?

IBD research suggests that question isn't as impossible as it might sound. Sure, no one could've predicted exactly which stocks would do best. But sketching a profile of the big winners would've been easy. Research shows that if a stock meets the CAN SLIM standards, it has a much better chance of delivering big gains than a hope-and-a-prayer laggard does.
In early 2009, the economy had been battered by a recession. The toughest chore was finding stocks that met the A in CAN SLIM.

The A stands for annual earnings growth of at least 25% in each of the past three years. The recession made that difficult. In March 2009, a stock would've needed to show big growth in 2006, 2007 and 2008.
Which stocks cleared the hurdle?
Actually, there were quite a few. But because a quality stock should be purchased only out of a proper base, an investor had to be patient.

Baidu (BIDU) boosted earnings 313% in 2006, 101% in 2007 and 91% in 2008. An investor, though, had to wait about five months after the March 12, 2009, follow-through day as Baidu continued to base. The China-based online search engine stock formed a gigantic cup-with-handle base 1 and broke out in September 2009 2. The stock climbed 306% in 19 months. Other stocks also met the annual test. They included Priceline (PCLN), Deckers Outdoor (DECK), OpenText (OTEX), American Public Education (APEI), BMC Software (BMC), Google (GOOG), Apple (AAPL), Newmont Mining (NEM), MasterCard (MA), Concho Resources (CXO) and Visa (V).
Did all turn into winners? No. That's why an investor should wait for a proper base and a breakout in strong volume.
Did the 25% rule screen out any big winners?

Well, Netflix (NFLX) fell just shy of satisfying the A. In 2007, EPS grew 23%. Two pennies more, and the growth would've been 25%. With 148% growth in 2006 and 43% in 2008 sandwiched around that 23%, few investors would've snubbed Netflix over a tiny miss.On March 12, 2009, the S&P 500 and NYSE composite delivered a follow-through day, confirming a market uptrend was under way.With hindsight, we know this was a great time to buy stocks. Stocks remained in the red early Tuesday afternoon as weak U.S. economic data outweighed bullish earnings reports and signs that Europe was making progress in resolving its debt crisis. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.4%. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 were each down 0.2%. Volume was higher across the board. The market opened a bit higher but turned…
Stocks opened higher Friday after a November jobs report fell short of expectations, but left room for optimism.
The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 added 1.1% each. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 1%. In early trading, volume was lower compared with the same time Thursday.
Financials led the Dow, with Bank of America  (BAC) and JPMorgan (JPM) up more than 3% each.

The addition of 140,000 jobs in November fell short of expectations. But it was in line with the average job growth of about 130,000 in recent months. The average workweek held rock steady at 34.3 hours.

Among leaders in the stock market, Ultra Salon  (ULTA) surged 5% in early trade after reporting late Thursday its third-quarter sales and earnings topped expectations. The stock had fallen more than 8% below a 74.10 buy point, triggering a loss-cutting sell rule. It is now rising from the 10-week line and is just below its buy point.

Spreadtrum Communications  (SPRD) climbed 4% in heavy trade. The China-based maker of chips for mobile communications is rising off its 10-week moving average. The stock cleared a deep cup-with-handle base in October.

Concho Resources  (CXO) jumped 3%, extending a breakout above a 99.57 buy point. The oil producer, focused on Permian basin production in West Texas, doubled its sales growth in each of the past two quarters.

Most Sector Leaders rose Friday, led by medical and consumer-related stocks such as Apple (AAPL) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), after consumer confidence rose. Volume was mostly lower, however. Apple rose for the third session in four, climbing 6.02 to 522.41 in average volume. The iPad maker is edging back toward its all-time high of 526.29 reached last Wednesday before…
The major indexes finished with sizable losses, but off their session lows, as the NYSE composite fared worst with a 0.8% decline.

The stock, which fell 3% during the regular session, has been extended after staging a rebound off its 10-week moving average in March.

Stocks were lower at midday Wednesday after Fitch downgraded Greece's credit rating, saying that Athens was likely to default even after it received a new round of bailout funds.
The Dow Jones industrial average, the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 each slipped 0.2%. Volume was slightly lower compared with the same time Tuesday, down 1% on the Nasdaq and 3% on the NYSE.

Wal-Mart (WMT) was down 2% in heavy volume, weighing on the Dow, after the world's biggest retailer reported weaker-than-expected Q4 earnings on Tuesday. Dell (DELL) plunged 6%, hamstringing the Nasdaq 100, after it also posted weak Q4 results.

Fitch said Wednesday that it cut Greece's debt rating deeper into junk territory, saying that "default is highly likely in the near term" even after European leaders approved a fresh rescue package for the debt-saddled country.

Meanwhile, U.S. existing-home sales rose 4% in January to 4.57 million, an 18-month high but below expectations for 4.63 million. Meanwhile, mortgage applications tumbled last week, raising concerns about the housing market's nascent recovery.

IBD 50 stock Herbalife (HLF) jumped 6% in heavy volume as it broke out to new highs. The company reported late Tuesday its Q4 earnings rose 25% to 86 cents, beating estimates for 72 cents. Revenue rose 20% to $884.6 million; analysts expected a 16% gain. The network marketer of nutritional and dietary supplements gave Q1 earnings guidance in line with analyst views and gave revenue guidance above expectations.

InvenSense (INVN), also an IBD 50 issue, jumped 6%. The maker of motion-processing chips and software has rebounded after last week's pullback in some heavy trade. It is 52% above its IPO-base buy point of 11.95.

On the downside, DealerTrack Holdings (TRAK) toppled 9% to its 50-day line in massive volume. The provider of software services to auto dealerships beat EPS and revenue expectations. But it offered full-year EPS guidance of 99 cents to $1.06 vs. a consensus forecast of $1.08.

Discount retailer Dollar Tree (DLTR) also sank to its 50-day line, dropping 3% in strong volume. It posted better-than-expected Q4 profit and sales but gave a cautious outlook for the first quarter. The stock had hit a new high intraday Tuesday before closing down 1.5%.

Stocks remained lower in early afternoon trading Wednesday following weaker-than-expected economic data in the U.S., Europe and China.
The Nasdaq was down 0.5%, the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average each fell 0.2%. Volume was mixed compared with the same time Tuesday, up 2% on the Nasdaq and down 1% on the NYSE.

Wal-Mart (WMT) lost 2% in heavy volume, weighing on the Dow, after the world's biggest retailer reported weaker-than-expected Q4 earnings on Tuesday. The stock is now below its 50-day moving average. Dell (DELL) plunged 6%, hamstringing the Nasdaq 100, after it also posted weak Q4 results.

U.S. existing-home sales rose less than expected in January while service- and manufacturing-sector activity in the 17-member euro area shrank this month, and China's export orders fell to an eight-month low, according to separate reports Wednesday.

Meanwhile, Fitch said Wednesday that it cut Greece's debt rating deeper into junk territory, saying that "default is highly likely in the near term" even after European leaders approved a fresh rescue package for the debt-saddled country.

IBD 50 stock Herbalife (HLF) jumped 6% in heavy volume as it broke out to new highs. The company reported late Tuesday its Q4 earnings rose 25% to 86 cents, beating estimates for 72 cents. Revenue rose 20% to $884.6 million; analysts expected a 16% gain. The network marketer of nutritional and dietary supplements gave Q1 earnings guidance in line with analyst views and gave revenue guidance above expectations.
The stock is now 4% past a 63.50 entry in a cup base, putting it in buying range.

InvenSense (INVN), also an IBD 50 issue, jumped 4%, backing off an earlier 8% gain. The maker of motion-processing chips and software has rebounded after last week's pullback in some heavy trade. It is 48% above its IPO-base buy point of 11.95.

On the downside, DealerTrack Holdings (TRAK) toppled 9% to its 50-day line in massive volume. The provider of software services to auto dealerships beat EPS and revenue expectations. But it offered full-year EPS guidance of 99 cents to $1.06 vs. a consensus forecast of $1.08.

Discount retailer Dollar Tree (DLTR) also sank to its 50-day line, dropping 3% in strong volume. The company posted better-than-expected Q4 profit and sales but gave a cautious outlook for the first quarter. The stock had hit a new high intraday Tuesday before closing down 1.5%. It's now back below its 86.74 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern.
TJX (TJX), another discount retailer, sank 1% after its Q1 forecast also disappointed investors. The stock is extended from a buy point after making multiple trips to its 50-day line.
Oil stocks Concho Resources (CXO) and Continental Resources (CLR) are due to report Q4 earnings after the market close.

While the indexes posted sizable gains Tuesday, sector leaders took a more nonchalant approach. Gains were mostly small. Volume was sharply lower for most top-rated stocks. Overall, the nondescript action among leaders combined with lower volume for the major indexes suggested that the gains in the indexes were all hat and no cowboy. Apparel retailer Lululemon Athletica (LULU), Chinese search…
Stocks remained higher late Thursday afternoon, led by drugmakers and biotech stocks, following positive economic data. Chipmaker InvenSense (INVN) also continued to rebound.
The Nasdaq was up 0.5%, and the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average each rose 0.3%. Volume was slightly higher on both major exchanges compared with the same time Wednesday.

Initial jobless claims held steady last week at 351,000, the lowest level since the early days of the recession in March 2008. Wall Street had expected a small increase. Also, the Federal Housing Finance Agency's index of home prices rose a better-than-expected 0.7% in December.
Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR) paced the IBD 50, jumping 8% in heavy volume after Q4 profit and sales smashed estimates. The stock is trying to regain its 10-week moving average.

Meanwhile, therapeutic drugmaker Vivus (VVUS) rocketed 88% after reporting that a Food & Drug Administration advisory panel voted 20-2 in favor its weight-loss drug Qnexa. The FDA had rejected the drug in 2010, citing the potential risks of elevated heart rate, psychiatric problems and birth defects. The FDA is expected to issue a final decision by mid-April.

Elsewhere in the IBD 50, InvenSense stepped up 2%, adding to a two-day rebound after last week's pullback. The maker of motion-sensing chips and software cleared an IPO base in January. It is 54% above that base's 11.95 buy point.

New Internet issue Angie's List (ANGI) popped 11%, paring earlier gains, after reporting late Thursday its losses narrowed and revenue improved sharply during the fourth quarter. The company also said paid memberships rose 78% to 1.1 million.

Retailers posted mixed results. Arkansas-based department store chain Dillard's (DDS) gapped up to a 9% gain in heavy trade. It reported that Q4 profit climbed 43% vs. a year ago, much better than expected. But revenue rose just 2%, just below views. The stock cleared a cup-with-handle base Feb. 17. It is now 12% past the 50.85 buy point.
Target (TGT) also climbed, rising 3% in strong volume after its Q4 profit report beat expectations. But midtier retailer Kohl's (KSS) plunged 6% on a disappointing 2012 forecast.

Energy stocks were also mixed. Concho Resources (CXO) was down 5%, rebounding somewhat from an earlier 7% drop, after reporting that hedging strategies widened the company's unadjusted losses. On an adjusted basis, earnings rose 53% to $1.15 a share, short of estimates. Revenue rose 48% to $478.4 million, above views.
The stock cleared a 104.93 handle buy point Jan. 25. It is still 5% above that buy point.

But Continental Resources (CLR) was up 2% and at new highs after reporting better-than-expected Q4 earnings thanks to higher oil prices and rising output in the oil-rich Bakken shale region of North Dakota and Montana.
Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) pulled back 6% to its 50-day line after it topped fiscal first-quarter earnings expectations, but missed revenue estimates and offered weak Q2 guidance.

Also Thursday, MercadoLibre  (MELI) was down 1% after JPMorgan downgraded the stock to neutral from overweight. The Argentina-based company is expected to report after the close that Q4 profit rose 42% vs. a year ago, which would mark the 12th straight quarter of double- or triple-digit growth. Revenue is seen rising a healthy 40%.

Big losses in below-average volume were the order of the day Wednesday for both the market and sector leaders. Under that scenario, it's hard to attach great significance to the price action. This is a holiday week, which normally pulls down volume. The Relative Strength line might be a better way of assessing stocks during a market correction. So let's…

While the major indexes all scored modest gains Wednesday, sector-leading stocks mostly declined, albeit in soft volume. Thirteen stocks were highlighted atop their sectors as of Wednesday's Research Tables. Nine of them fell. On the upside, Camelot Information Systems (CIS), Ebix (EBIX) and Priceline.com (PCLN) all advanced in above-average turnover. Camelot, a Chinese IT services outsourcer, rose 1.05, or 4%,…

Stocks fell Monday as overseas economic news offset some better-than-expected U.S. data. China cut its economic growth forecast, while the euro zone purchasing managers index slipped. Both trumped better-than-expected domestic factory and services data. The Nasdaq lost 0.9%, near its session low. It marked the tech-heavy index's biggest one-day percentage loss so far this year. The Nasdaq hadn't fallen by…

Market leaders notched sharp losses Tuesday as most major indexes suffered their largest single-day loss since Oct. 19. China New Borun (BORN) caved 1.60 to 12.82 in fast trade and undercut its 50-day moving average for the first time since early September. The corn-based alcohol maker late Monday reported a 23% rise in Q3 earnings to 37 cents a share,…

Sector leaders mostly fell Wednesday, while the major indexes rallied late in the day to finish mixed. Leaders in IBD's Computer, Internet and Software sectors generally slid in big turnover, hit by negative news that sparked a broad sell-off in tech stocks. The negative news included data center service firm Equinix's  (EQIX) warning late Tuesday, as well as Morgan…

When you scan for stocks to buy, the results could be comprised of names that pass a three-step test. Step one is a precondition: The general market must be in an uptrend. If it is, then step two is to find out what industries are leading the market. The third step is to look for individual stocks that are leaders…
Stocks remained mildly lower in late-afternoon trading but were still off intraday lows Wednesday following weaker-than-expected economic data in the U.S., Europe and China.

The Nasdaq was down 0.4% and the S&P 500 eased 0.3% after sinking as much as 0.6% and 0.5%, respectively. The Dow Jones industrial average was 0.1% lower. Volume was down 2% on the Nasdaq and NYSE compared with the same time Tuesday.

Wal-Mart Stores (WMT), which slid 4% on Tuesday, lost another 2% in heavy volume, weighing on the Dow, a day after the world's biggest retailer reported weaker-than-expected Q4 earnings. The stock is now below its 50-day moving average. Dell (DELL) plunged 6%, hamstringing the Nasdaq 100, after it also posted weak Q4 results.

U.S. existing-home sales rose less than expected in January while service- and manufacturing-sector activity in the 17-member euro area shrank this month, and China's export orders fell to an eight-month low, according to separate reports Wednesday.

Homebuilders were among the biggest losers Wednesday, with Toll Bros. (TOL), Lennar (LEN) and KBHome (KBH) all falling on the disappointing home sales data and a separate report showing that mortgage applications tumbled last week.

Meanwhile, Fitch on Wednesday cut Greece's credit rating deeper into junk territory, saying that "default is highly likely in the near term," as the latest European bailout for Athens requires private bond holders to take big losses. Bank shares fell, led by Citigroup (C) and Bank of America (BAC), amid concerns about their exposure to Europe.

IBD 50 stock Herbalife (HLF) bucked the trend, jumping 6% in heavy volume as it broke out to new highs. The company reported late Tuesday that Q4 earnings rose 25% on a 20% gain in revenue, both of which topped expectations. The network marketer of nutritional and dietary supplements gave Q1 earnings guidance in line with analyst views and gave revenue guidance above expectations.
The stock is now just under 5% past a 63.50 entry in a cup base, putting it in buying range.

InvenSense (INVN), also an IBD 50 issue, jumped 5%, backing off an earlier 8% gain. The maker of motion-processing chips and software has rebounded after last week's pullback in some heavy trade. It is 50% above its IPO-base buy point of 11.95.

On the downside, DealerTrack Holdings (TRAK) tumbled more than 9% to its 50-day line in massive volume. The provider of software services to auto dealerships beat EPS and revenue expectations. But it offered full-year EPS guidance that fell short of the consensus forecast.

Discount retailer Dollar Tree (DLTR) pared its losses after also sinking to its 50-day line. The stock was down nearly 2% after the company posted better-than-expected Q4 profit and sales but gave a cautious Q1 outlook. The stock had hit a new high intraday Tuesday before closing down 1.5%. It's now just above its 86.74 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern.

TJX Cos. (TJX), another discount retailer, was down fractionally after paring earlier losses prompted by the company's disappointing Q1 forecast. The stock is extended from a buy point after making multiple trips to its 50-day line.
Oil stocks Concho Resources (CXO) and Continental Resources (CLR) are due to report Q4 earnings after the market close.

The Nasdaq composite sank 2.7%, while the NYSE composite and S&P 500 both tumbled 2.1%. Volume rose across the board, according to preliminary data.

After hours, Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) plunged as it reported Q1 revenue that missed views. Q1 EPS beat estimates, but HP also offered Q2 and full-year targets for EPS and revenue that fell short of expectations. While HP is a tech bellwether, the stock has a poor RS Rating of 38 and a mediocre Composite Rating of 70.

Also in late trading, Chesapeake Energy (CHK) dipped after reporting Q4 EPS that topped views, but sales that missed forecasts. The stock gained 5% during the regular session, helped by news that BHP Billiton (BHP) plans to buy shale gas reserves from Chesapeake for $4.75 billion. Chesapeake is extended after clearing resistance around 30 in a consolidation that dates to October 2009.

During the regular session, the highly rated stocks falling in strong volume included Apple (AAPL), Baidu (BIDU) and Netflix (NFLX). Apple shed 3% and found support at its 10-week moving average. Baidu lost 5% and Netflix 6%, as both stayed above their 10-week lines.

The top-rated companies slated to post earnings on Wednesday include Avago Technologies (AVGO), Concho Resources (CXO) and Priceline.com (PCLN). The day's economic reports will include data for existing home sales and same-store sales for chain stores.

After a week that battered many leading stocks, few are still in decent shape.
The major indexes are deep into a correction, so buying stocks should be off limits. That shouldn't be a problem considering how few stocks are in potential buy areas.

Priceline (PCLN) appears to be getting support at 500, a round number, but has yet to clear a 552.25 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. The stock's handle deepened to 13% last week. That's a touch outside the normal range of 8% to 12%. Still, the stock finished near the highs of the week and just 6% off its 52-week high. Priceline's Relative Strength line is already at a new high.
Despite tough competition and global economic uncertainty, the online travel services leader beat estimates with a 78% surge in Q2 earnings Aug. 4. Sales grew 44%, the biggest in 12 quarters.

Nu Skin Enterprises (NUS) pulled a reversal in the face of the market's sell-off. But the stock is having a tought time holding above its 10-week moving average after regaining the key support level last week and remains near a 39.45 buy point.

The company recently topped views with a 30% rise in Q2 earnings and a 9% gain in sales. Nu Skin is eyeing growth in emerging markets, particularly China. It's also gearing up to introduce its latest ageLoc anti-aging products in October.
Baidu (BIDU) has erased the bulk of its gains from its June 30 breakout. Tuesday's rebound lifted it back to 3% above a 139.19 buy point and mildly above its 10-week moving average.

Last month, China's top Internet search firm delivered its sixth straight quarter of triple-digit profit growth. Baidu's share of the Chinese Web search market edged up to 75.9% in Q2 from 75.8% in Q1, according to research firm Analysis International.
IBD 50 stocks had another rough week as the market correction deepened. On average, the IBD 50 components fell 8.2% — in line with the broad market.

Coal producer Walter Energy (WLT) was the worst performer last week. It nose-dived 40% after reporting much worse-than-expected quarterly results late Aug. 3. Its rebound this week is muted so far. The coal energy group now languishes within the bottom quarter of IBD's industry group rankings at 158th as of Wednesday's IBD.

Catalyst Health Solutions (CHSI) and Sohu.com (SOHU) continue to struggle this week after both tumbled nearly 20% each last week. The Nasdaq fell 0.5%, cutting its intraday loss in half. Research In Motion (RIMM) dropped 3% after unveiling its new BlackBerry device. Rival Apple (AAPL), which makes the iPhone, ticked up a fraction.
Meanwhile the S&P 500 lost 0.5%, while the Dow and NYSE composite gave up 0.4% each.
Volume rose on the Nasdaq, giving the tech-laden index a distribution day. Trade fell on the NYSE.

Venoco (VQ) gapped down and slumped nearly 7% in more than twice its average trade. Before the open, the oil producer reported Q2 earnings of a nickel a share, badly missing views of 17 cents a share. The stock managed to close above its 50-day moving average. It's testing the 50-day for the second time since clearing an eight-month wide-and-loose base on June 10.

Rovi (ROVI) lost 3% in fast trade. That marked its third decline in above-average volume in the past four sessions. Despite this, the stock remains 5% past a 40.16 buy point. Last week, the provider of digital media services delivered Q2 results above views and raised its full-year profit outlook.
Ancestry.com (ACOM) fell 4% in heavy trading. It gave back the bulk of Monday's move. The stock cleared a 21.02 buy point from a cup base Monday.

On the upside, Herbalife (HLF) gapped up and surged 12% in about six times normal trade. The stock cleared a 51.89 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. Herbalife had a prior handle trigger at 50.10. Late Monday, the nutritional supplements maker smashed views with a 69% jump in Q2 earnings and a 21% gain in sales. The firm also gave a strong full-year profit outlook. It raised its quarterly dividend to 25 cents a share from 20 cents.

Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) gapped up and rallied 9% in triple its average trade. Earlier Tuesday, the IT services provider delivered Q2 earnings and sales above views. It also guided Q3 results ahead of analysts estimates. The stock was up more than 15% at session peak.
After the close, Priceline.com (PCLN) bolted 20% after reporting Q2 earnings well above views. The provider of online travel services also guided Q3 results ahead of analysts' estimates.

Earnings Wednesday: Agrium (AGU), Cardtronics (CATM), Concho Resources (CXO), DG FastChannel (DGIT), El Paso Pipeline Partners (EPB), MercadoLibre (MELI), Par Pharmaceutical (PRX) and 99 Cents Only Stores (NDN).

The ADP employment survey and the ISM services index will also be out Wednesday.A round of mixed earnings reports and economic data pressured stocks Tuesday, but equities managed to close off session lows.Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?

The major indexes lost ground for the week, as the market's uptrend came under pressure. Still, many IBD 50 stocks held up well through the week's choppiness. For the week, IBD 50 stocks on average were up fractionally, outperforming the major indexes. The NYSE shed 1%, while the Nasdaq and S&P 500 each dropped 0.6%. Several leading stocks are working…

Sector leaders were mostly weaker Thursday amid a broad sell-off in the general market. Silver Wheaton (SLW) gapped down, shedding 2.65 to 40.74 in volume nearly twice its average. The stock has given up 10% since reaching a new high on Feb. 28. Silver's price fell sharply, part of a broader commodity rout. Another commodity stock, Concho Resources (CXO), fell…

The major indexes traded mixed during Monday's afternoon trading after a mixed bag of economic data earlier in the day.The NYSE composite, bolstered by gains in mainly defensive stocks including hospitals, grains and ethical drugs, rose 0.3%. IBD's Media-Books and Media-Radio/TV industry groups also outperformed with gains of at least 1%. The S&P 500 was up 0.2%. The Nasdaq slumped 0.3% and was trading near its session lows; it had been up 0.6% soon after the open. Volume edged higher on the NYSE and mildly lower on the Nasdaq.Stocks got an early boost on a rosy February reading from the Chicago purchasing managers index, but January pending home sales declined. January personal income rose more than expected in the U.S., up 1%, but a 0.2% gain in personal spending was weaker than forecast.Among top-rated stocks within Monday's IBD 50, some cyclical stocks were poised to finish the final day of February with gains.  Silver Wheaton (SLW) was up 2% in above-average trade. The stock on Friday worked on the fourth day of a possible handle. But on Monday, the silver streaming firm edged past the potential handle's high of 41.89, making it a shorter-than-ideal handle. The current base is third-stage, which tends to carry more risk than a first- or second-stage pattern.However, Concho Resources (CXO) and Travelzoo (TZOO) both fell more than 3% in above-average trade. The latter undercut its 50-day moving average on Feb. 3 in the heaviest volume since its rally past 20 last August, a clear sign of a correction. The online discount travel firm is forming a new base and currently stands 25% below a 53.21 peak.On the downside, First Solar (FSLR), a huge winner in 2007, slumped nearly 5% in active trade. The low-cost maker of silicon-free solar panels has fallen 12% over the past six sessions after running up fast in January. Last week the Tempe, Ariz.-based firm reported a 9% increase in Q4 earnings per share as sales fell 5% from year-ago levels.Sales grew 24% for the year, but the pace of growth has slowed considerably from a 273% annual sales boost in 2007 and 147% rise in 2008.

The country's top-performing funds the past three months have been easing off the buying pedal. They've been adding oil-related stocks such as Concho Resources (CXO), Gulfport Energy (GPOR) and Carbo Ceramics (CRR) in their latest reporting periods. Crude oil prices have been steadily creeping up the past few months reaching almost $91 a barrel. The recent political unrest in Egypt…
IBD offers three key stock screens that are refreshed once per week: the IBD 50, Your Weekly Review and the Big Cap 20.
This Investor's Corner column will look at why you might want to use all three as you form a watch list for your stock investments.
It also will explain what sets each one apart from the others.
For the most part, you should consider using the different screens because each sheds light on a separate part of the stock market.

• IBD 50: This screen, which appears in the Monday edition, should be viewed as a list of the stocks that have been leading the market. Among the big winners featured in the IBD 50 in recent years were Apple (AAPL), Baidu (BIDU), Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Concho Resources (CXO), Priceline.com (PCLN) and Lululemon Athletica (LULU).
As you can tell by these names, they tend to be No. 1 in their industries. This satisfies the L in IBD's CAN SLIM investment method, or "Leader."

No matter whether the market is mired in a correction or rallying, the IBD 50 features stocks showing strength. So when the general environment is bearish, you still can see which names are faring better than most.

Oftentimes, these resilient stocks will turn into the market's new leaders once it finally gets back into rally mode. The IBD 50, in effect, is giving you some insight into the market's future leaders.
• Your Weekly Review: This screen is the widest of the three.
It appears in every Friday edition. It can run to 120 stocks or more, but often falls below that level when the market is struggling.
All stocks in this screen have EPS and Relative Price Strength ratings of at least 85 (both out of a best-possible 99). They must also be trading within 15% of their highs.

This screen has a less stringent requirement for average volume. If you see a stock in Your Weekly Review and wonder why it's not in the IBD 50, frequently the difference comes from the issue being somewhat thinly traded.

It's best to trade stocks that can be held by big institutional investors who have the power to really drive it higher. But being thinly traded is not necessarily a fatal flaw, and so this IBD screen generally offers some small-cap or even micro-cap names.
• Big Cap 20: This screen contains growth stocks that are real heavyweights.
It runs in Tuesday's IBD. Because Big Cap 20 stocks all have a market capitalization of at least $15 billion, they generally are less volatile.

That makes this screen particularly well-suited for stock investors who are more risk averse — or those looking to add a relatively calm name to an otherwise aggressive portfolio. There are still no guarantees with big-cap stocks, but overall such names are steadier.

Even so, Big Cap 20 issues generally show strong growth, meaning double-digit percentage gains in EPS and sales. They lead their industry group, holding better IBD Composite Ratings than similarly sized companies in their sector.
The Big Cap 20 lineup has recently featured some stocks with lackluster fundamentals. That reflects the state of the market, which has slumped and exhibited volatility.

When you mull buying Big Cap 20 issues, use the same rules as always. Forget natural gas. Bring on the oil.
What's old is new again, and nowhere is that more so than with onshore U.S. oil.
America's love affair with natural gas seems to have vanished into thin air, as a glut from frenetic shale-basin gas production has caused prices to stay stuck in the low-$4-per-Mcf range.

With oil prices above $110 a barrel and output still down in the deep-water Gulf of Mexico after last year's BP (BP) oil spill, oil and gas companies are following the money to U.S. onshore oilfields.
Old onshore oil basins such as the Permian in West Texas look trusty again, not rusty.
"When you have oil trading at 25-to-1 to gas, obviously the economics are much, much better for oil," said analyst Neal Dingmann of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.
Natural-gas-focused firms such as Chesapeake Energy (CHK), Petrohawk Energy (HK), SandRidge Energy (SD) and EOG Resources (EOG) have changed gears to pursue more oil.

From small independents to majors like Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX), oil companies are stepping up old-fashioned vertical drilling or secondary recovery activity in conventional fields. Many oil firms had left the Permian years ago after prices plummeted.

Apache (APA), which bought BP's (BP) Permian assets last year, recently opened a regional office in Midland, Texas, to support new activity there. The Permian still boasts some of the largest oil reserves in the U.S.

"Conventional means lower-cost projects and more profits," said Gary Taylor, senior writer for Platts Oilgram News. "Compa nies are making sure they haven't overlooked anything, checking reservoirs they might have ignored or missed in the past."
Mature, Not Finished
Occidental (OXY) is drilling in a productive conventional oilfield it said it found last year in the well-worn Elk Hills of California, an area first drilled a century ago.
"The idea of trying to exploit additional production from mature fields is a particularly hot area right now," Taylor said.

Besides vertical drilling in new fields in old basins, companies are using another traditional strategy called "enhanced oil recovery," which includes CO2 flooding, to squeeze every last drop of oil out of mature wells.
Improved pumping equipment and the addition of new fluids have improved the industry's ability to force more oil from aging reservoirs, Taylor says.
In looking for new U.S. onshore oil, firms are borrowing the new (and costlier) technology used to unlock natural gas from tight shale — namely horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing.
The most promising region for this is the Bakken Shale in North Dakota and Montana. There, scores of oil firms are at work to recover the billions of barrels of oil trapped in its hard rock.

The Eagle Ford shale basin in South Texas, which holds both oil and gas, is another emerging hot spot, as is the even newer oil play, the Niobrara Shale in the Denver-Julesburg basin, which includes parts of Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska and Wyoming.
Horizontal drilling and fracturing techniques are even being tried in shale rock in the Permian — by Pioneer (PXD), Concho (CXO) and Apache, to name a few.
They're also being used to find oil in gas basins such as the massive Barnett Shale in Texas, where new "oil windows" have been found.

At a recent industry conference, the CEO of Chesapeake, which has been active in the Barnett, said he would need to see natural gas prices rise to $7 or $8 before he would want to drill more gas wells.

"Given the abundant supply of gas out there," Dingmann said, "I don't see that happening for a couple of years at least."Forget natural gas. Bring on the oil.What's old is new again, and nowhere is that more so than with onshore U.S. oil.America's love affair with natural gas seems to have vanished into thin air, as a glut from frenetic shale-basin gas production has caused prices to stay stuck in the low-$4-per-Mcf range.With oil prices above $110 a barrel and output still down in the deep-water Gulf of Mexico after last year's BP (BP) oil spill, oil and gas companies are following the money to U.S. onshore oilfields.Old onshore oil basins such as the Permian in West Texas look trusty again, not rusty."When you have oil trading at 25-to-1 to gas, obviously the economics are much, much better for oil," said analyst Neal Dingmann of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.Natural-gas-focused firms such as Chesapeake Energy (CHK), Petrohawk Energy (HK), SandRidge Energy (SD) and EOG Resources (EOG) have changed gears to pursue more oil.From small independents to majors like Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX), oil companies are stepping up old-fashioned vertical drilling or secondary recovery activity in conventional fields. Stocks rebounded from recent losses to score their first gain in three days Monday. The Dow Jones industrial average led, rising 0.9%. The S&P 500 rose 0.8%, recouping most of Friday's loss. But the Nasdaq lagged with a 0.6% gain. Still, the tech-laden index closed back above the 4000 level, despite continued weakness in biotech stocks. The Medical-Biomed/Biotech industry group…

June got off to a gloomy start, as stocks stumbled in a seesaw session Tuesday. Worries over Europe's debt crisis, China's economic growth and tension between Israel and Lebanon offset better-than-expected domestic economic data.
Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?
Click here to watch the latest Market Wrap video!

The NYSE composite dropped 1.9%, hurt by oil and steel issues. The S&P 500 and Dow lost 1.7% and 1.1%, respectively. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq fell 1.5% and closed back under its 200-day moving average. Volume fell on both exchanges.
Acme Packet (APKT) reversed from a new record high and dropped 6% in over twice its average trade. The stock had been holding tough during the correction.
Sirona Dental Systems (SIRO) shed 6% in heavy trading. But the stock eased off its worst levels after support at its 200-day moving average.
Perrigo (PRGO) dropped 5% in brisk volume and closed back under its 200-day moving average. The stock is working on a new base, but recent price action has been wide and loose.

On the upside, ev3 (EVVV) gapped up and bolted 17% on takeover news. Covidien (COV) agreed to buy the medical gear maker for $2.6 billion in cash, or $22.50 a share. That marks a premium of nearly 19% over Friday's close.
After the close, Collective Brands (PSS) tumbled 9% after reporting Q1 sales below analysts estimates.
Data on pending home sales and vehicle sales will be out Wednesday. Medical Action (MDCI) also reports earnings Wednesday.
U.S. Stocks Close Near Lows
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks swayed from losses to gains before ultimately finishing lower on a late sell-off Tuesday.
The NYSE composite dropped 1.9%, the S&P 500 1.7%, the Nasdaq 1.5% and the Dow 1.1%. According to preliminary data, volume rose on both major exchanges.
The late selling came after a report said Israeli warplanes had come under fire from Lebanon.
Energy and steel-related industry groups were the worst performers. Defensive industries such as food and beverage companies, rose.
U.S. Stocks Waver In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks continued to trade without much direction late Tuesday.
The Dow and Nasdaq rose 0.4% and 0.1%, respectively. The NYSE composite fell 0.3% and the S&P 500 0.2%. Volume was tracking higher on the NYSE and a tad lower on the Nasdaq.
Apple (AAPL) climbed 3% on news that sales of its iPad have topped 2 million units since hitting U.S. store shelves April 3. The tablet device went on sale in a number of overseas markets Friday.

Boston Beer (SAM) erased early losses and rose 2% to a fresh all-time high. The stock recently found support at its 50-day moving average. Earlier this month, the brewer beat expectations with a 340% pop in Q1 earnings.

Concho Resources (CXO) erased morning losses climbed 2%, regaining its 50-day moving average in heavy trading. The stock bucked weakness in other oil issues. In early May, the oil and gas producer smashed Q1 views.

Collective Brands (PSS) was off its intraday low, but still down 2% ahead of its Q1 results after the close. The shoe retailer is expected to deliver earnings of 75 cents a share, up 27%. Sales are slated to rise 3% to $888.2 million.
U.S. Stocks Improve; Blue Chips Lead
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks improved some in afternoon trading, with the Dow leading the pack.

The blue-chip index climbed 0.7% to a new session high. It was the only index to do so. Twenty-four of 30 components traded higher. IBM (IBM) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) were the two biggest point gainers.
Meanwhile, the Nasdaq gained 0.4% and the S&P 500 0.2%. The NYSE composite lost a fraction, hurt by losses in oil, energy and steel stocks. Volume turned lower on both exchanges.
August gold settled at $1,226.80 an ounce, up $11.80. July crude slipped 2 cents to $73.95 a barrel.

Universal Display (PANL) surged 13% in fast trade. Earlier Tuesday, Canaccord Adams raised the stock to buy from hold. Universal Display makes light emitting diodes for flat panel displays. The firm has lost money for a number of quarters, but its sales growth ramped up in recent periods. Its Composite Rating is 84.
Edwards Lifesciences (EW) reversed earlier losses and climbed 4% in fast trade. The stock regained in 50-day moving average and is working on a new base.
Stocks Seesaw In Early Afternoon Trading
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks wavered in mixed territory in early afternoon trade. The major indexes have had trouble holding gains today after turning positive.
The Dow rose 0.4%, boosted by gains in IBM (IBM) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) . Earlier, the blue-chip index had been up as much as 0.7% and down as much as 1%.
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite fell 0.2%, and the S&P 500 0.1%. The Nasdaq was flat. Volume was tracking higher on both exchanges.
China Agritech (CAGC) erased earlier gains and skidded 7%. That puts the stock 61% off a 52-week high. With a Composite Rating of 81, however, it can't be considered a leader.
Yanzhou Coal (YZC) gapped down and fell 5% in fast trade. It erased a chunk of gains from the past two sessions. Earlier a report said that Chinese factory activity slowed in May.

Xryatex (XRTX) turned lower after briefly turning positive. It shed 5% in fast trade. Last month, the data storage firm swung to a better-than-expected Q1 profit and reported its first quarter of revenue growth in over a year. It has a Composite Rating of 89.
August gold climbed $11.60 to $1,226.80 an ounce. That boosted gold producers.
Randgold Resources (GOLD) rallied 4% and neared its May 12 record high. Barrick Gold (ABX) and Iamgold (IAG) gained 3% apiece.
U.S. Stocks Turn Mostly Lower At Midday
BY JONAH KERI
The major indexes gave up most of their brief intraday gains at midday Tuesday, with stocks continuing to trade narrowly mixed.

The Dow was up 0.1%. On the downside, the Nasdaq and S&P 500 both fell 0.3%, while the NYSE composite lost 0.4%. Volume swelled 14% on the NYSE and 3% on the Nasdaq compared with pre-holiday trading Friday.

Acme Packet (APKT) fell 3% in more than three times its usual turnover. The maker of technologies for videoconferencing and other interactive communications reversed lower after hitting an all-time high.
Perrigo (PRGO) slipped 2% in rapid volume. The drugmaker's stock ducked below its 50-day moving average.
On the upside, Concho Resources (CXO) advanced 2% in nearly triple its normal trade. The oil and natural gas exploration and development firm's stock rebounded above its 50-day moving average.
U.S. Stocks Turn Higher On Construction, Manufacturing Reports

July crude slipped 2 cents to $73.95 a barrel.Universal Display (PANL) surged 13% in fast trade. Earlier Tuesday, Canaccord Adams raised the stock to buy from hold. Universal Display makes light emitting diodes for flat panel displays. The firm has lost money for a number of quarters, but its sales growth ramped up in recent periods. Its Composite Rating is 84.Edwards Lifesciences (EW) reversed earlier losses and climbed 4% in fast trade. The stock regained in 50-day moving average and is working on a new base.Stocks Seesaw In Early Afternoon TradingBY VINCENT MAOStocks wavered in mixed territory in early afternoon trade. The major indexes have had trouble holding gains today after turning positive.The Dow rose 0.4%, boosted by gains in IBM (IBM) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) . Earlier, the blue-chip index had been up as much as 0.7% and down as much as 1%.Meanwhile, the NYSE composite fell 0.2%, and the S&P 500 0.1%. The Nasdaq was flat. Volume was tracking higher on both exchanges.China Agritech (CAGC) erased earlier gains and skidded 7%. That puts the stock 61% off a 52-week high. With a Composite Rating of 81, however, it can't be considered a leader.Yanzhou Coal (YZC) gapped down and fell 5% in fast trade. It erased a chunk of gains from the past two sessions. Earlier a report said that Chinese factory activity slowed in May.Xryatex (XRTX) turned lower after briefly turning positive. It shed 5% in fast trade. Last month, the data storage firm swung to a better-than-expected Q1 profit and reported its first quarter of revenue growth in over a year. It has a Composite Rating of 89.August gold climbed $11.60 to $1,226.80 an ounce. That boosted gold producers.Randgold Resources (GOLD) rallied 4% and neared its May 12 record high. Barrick Gold (ABX) and Iamgold (IAG) gained 3% apiece.U.S. Stocks Turn Mostly Lower At MiddayBY JONAH KERIThe major indexes gave up most of their brief intraday gains at midday Tuesday, with stocks continuing to trade narrowly mixed.The Dow was up 0.1%. On the downside, the Nasdaq and S&P 500 both fell 0.3%, while the NYSE composite lost 0.4%. Volume swelled 14% on the NYSE and 3% on the Nasdaq compared with pre-holiday trading Friday.Acme Packet (APKT) fell 3% in more than three times its usual turnover. The maker of technologies for videoconferencing and other interactive communications reversed lower after hitting an all-time high.Perrigo (PRGO) slipped 2% in rapid volume. The drugmaker's stock ducked below its 50-day moving average.On the upside, Concho Resources (CXO) advanced 2% in nearly triple its normal trade. The oil and natural gas exploration and development firm's stock rebounded above its 50-day moving average.U.S. Stocks Turn Higher On Construction, Manufacturing Reports
Stocks had a big comeback Wednesday and closed higher for the first time in three sessions.

Boosted by oil, coal, machinery and steel issues, the NYSE composite jumped 2.7%. The Nasdaq climbed 2.6%, regaining its 200-day moving average. And the Nasdaq took out the high of a short trading range.
Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?
Click here to watch the latest Market Wrap video!
Meanwhile, the S&P 500 and Dow gained 2.6% and 2.2%, respectively. Volume fell on the NYSE and rose on the Nasdaq.
Stocks had opened higher and then strengthened after news of much better than expected pending home sales.

Concho Resources (CXO) leapt 10% on triple its average trade. The stock regained its 50-day moving average. According to Briefing.com, the oil producer may benefit from the moratorium on offshore drilling.
Deckers Outdoor (DECK) reversed early losses and stepped up 6% on twice its average trade. The stock is working on a new base and sits just 5% off a 52-week high.

Thoratec (THOR) rallied 6% to a new record high on twice its average volume. The stock cleared a four-week consolidation. Thoratec makes circulatory support systems and diagnostic tests. Analysts see its full-year earnings rising 49%.
Earnings Thursday: Joy Global (JOYG) and Ulta Salon, Cosmetics and Fragrances (ULTA). The ADP employment survey, weekly jobless claims, productivity and unit labor costs will be out Thursday.
U.S. Stocks Come Back Strongly
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks rebounded strongly Wednesday, retaking the prior session's losses and then some.
The NYSE composite surged 2.7%, while the Nasdaq and S&P 500 rallied 2.6% each. The Dow gained 2.2%, with all 30 components finishing higher.
According to preliminary data, volume fell on both exchanges, despite the sharp gains.
Energy and Steel were the session's top-performing industry groups. Retail groups were some of the worst performers.
U.S. Stocks Ramp Up In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks rebounded from an earlier pullback and climbed to new session highs in late trading Wednesday. All major indexes were on pace for their first gain in three sessions.
The NYSE composite climbed 1.9%, while the Nasdaq and S&P 500 rallied 1.7% each. The Dow gained 1.5%. Turnover continued to track lower across the board.
BJ's Restaurants (BJRI) reversed morning losses and climbed 5% in fast trade. The stock regained its 50-day moving average. BJ's has met resistance at the line in recent sessions.
Likewise, Natus Medical (BABY) rose 3% after shedding earlier losses. It also regained its 50-day line. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has improved to B+ from D+ last month.

Parexel (PRXL) rebounded from an earlier 3% loss and gained 3% to just below its 50-day line. In late April, the clinical research firm beat views with a 12% rise in fiscal Q3 earnings. Analysts expect a 173% pop in its current quarterly profit.
U.S. Stocks Hold Near Session's Best Levels
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks hovered near new session highs after the dollar index weakened.

The Nasdaq was up 1.6%, thanks in part to gains in Google (GOOG) and Amgen (AMGN). The NYSE composite rose 1.5%, the S&P 500 1.4%, the Dow 1.1%. Turnover continued to track lower on both exchanges, but Nasdaq volume was picking up.

CommVault Systems (CVLT) bounced back from earlier losses and gained 4% in heavy volume. The stock has been volatile recently. But its Accumulation/Distribution Rating has climbed to A- from a worst-possible E in early May. CommVault makes management software. Its earnings and sales accelerated in recent quarters.

Avago Technologies (AVGO) rose 3% and regained its 50-day moving average. The stock's Relative Strength line is already at a new high ahead of price. Last year, the chipmaker's earnings fell 18%, but analysts see a 198% pop this year.

Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance (ULTA) reversed early gains, tumbling 7% and breaching its 50-day moving average. The beauty supplies retailer reports first-quarter results Thursday after the close. Analysts see profit surging 138% to 19 cents a share on sales of $315.2 million.

HHGregg (HGG) erased opening gains and fell 4% in heavy turnover. The stock touched a fresh record high in Tuesday's session but backed off sharply. Last week, the electronics retailer reported a 40% drop in fiscal Q4 profit.
U.S. Stocks Add To Gains
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks extended gains in early-afternoon trading Wednesday. The major averages regained all or nearly all of the prior session's losses.
The NYSE composite was up 1.5%, boosted by energy, oil, steel and airline issues. The Nasdaq rallied 1.4%, the S&P 500 1.3%, the Dow 1.1%. Volume was tracking lower across the board.

United Natural Foods (UNFI) gapped up and gained 6% in heavy trading. Before the open, the organic food distributor topped views with a 15% pop in fiscal Q3 earnings and an 11% rise in sales. United Natural pegged full-year profit between $1.55 and $1.58 a share vs. views for $1.54. It also guided full-year revenue above views and extended a distribution agreement with Whole Foods Market (WFMI).
It is not a leader, however. Its Composite Rating is 76, putting almost a quarter of all stocks ahead of it.
Thoratec (THOR) rallied 5% in fast trade. It neared the top of a four-week consolidation. The medical device maker's sales growth has accelerated in the past two quarters.

On the downside, Collective Brands (PSS) gapped below its 200-day moving average, diving 10% in huge trade. Late Tuesday, the shoe retailer reported a 42% increase in Q1 earnings, beating views. But sales rose 2%, missing views. Collective shares neared a four-month low. The stock has a Composite Rating of 76.
Fellow shoe retailer Shoe Carnival (SCVL) gapped down, off 5% after giving a disappointing second-quarter sales outlook. The stock had been down nearly 9% at its intraday low.
U.S. Stocks Hit Intraday Highs On Housing Report
BY JONAH KERI
The major indexes surged to session highs at midday Wednesday, as investors continued to embrace a strong home-sales report.
The Nasdaq and NYSE were up 1.5%, the S&P 500 1.4%, the Dow 1.2%. Volume sank 6% on the NYSE and 2% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Tuesday.
Discovery Communications (DISCA) rose 3% in above-average volume. The television program producer has a 97 IBD Composite Rating and a 97 Earnings Per Share Rating.

Deckers Outdoor (DECK) gained 3% in double its normal trade. The maker of Ugg boots, Teva sandals and other footwear has held up better than most stocks during the market's correction, maintaining a 95 Relative Price Strength Rating. It sits 8% off its 52-week high.
Avago Technologies (AVGO) advanced 2% in brisk turnover. After a rough 2009, the chipmaker now sports accelerating quarterly sales and earnings growth.
U.S. Stocks Expand Gains On Bullish Econ Data

5:15 p.m. Update: Stocks closed in split fashion after a choppy session Wednesday.
The Nasdaq gained 0.7%, helped by biotechs and a few big-cap techs. At session highs, the index was up 1.6%.
The NYSE composite lost 0.4%, dragged down by financial and energy sectors. The S&P 500 fell 0.1%, closing above its 50-day moving average, which it breached intraday. The Dow also lost 0.1%.
Turnover rose on both major exchanges, giving the NYSE composite its third distribution day in recent weeks.
The Financial Select Sector SPDR (XLF) fell nearly 3%, closing just above its 50-day line. President Obama unveiled financial reforms. Meanwhile, S&P cut ratings on 22 banks.
Fuqi International (FUQI) dropped 6% in about double average trade. The Chinese jewelry company extended its losing streak to five days and now sits 28% off its June 10 record high.
Oil and gas producer Concho Resources (CXO) fell 4% in heavy trading. But the stock found support at its 50-day moving average. Concho is one of eight energy stocks in this week's IBD 100.
Changyou.com (CYOU) slipped 2% in active trading. That extended the Chinese Internet gamer's losing streak to five sessions. But the stock closed near session highs after falling as much as 7%.
On the upside, STEC (STEC) erased early losses and climbed 4% in twice typical trade to close at an all-time high.
Longtop Financial Technologies (LFT) bounced back from a 6% loss to settle up 4%.
On the economic calendar Thursday are initial jobless claims, leading indicators and the Philly Fed index. Research In Motion (RIMM) will report earnings after Thursday's close.
4:15 p.m. Update: Nasdaq Rebounds While Others Sag
BY VINCENT MAO
Major stock indexes closed mixed after a seesaw session Wednesday.
The Nasdaq was the lone winner. It rose 0.7% and snapped a three-session decline. The NYSE composite fell 0.4%, while the Dow and S&P 500 slipped 0.1% each.
Volume jumped across the board. Decliners beat advancers 17-to-13 on the NYSE. Nasdaq advancers edged out decliners 7-to-6.
School and health care-related issues were among the session's top performers for a second straight day. Software stocks also scored gains.
Fertilizer, energy and financial groups were some of the worst performers.
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Pull Back In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks pulled back from session highs, but were still on pace to close higher for the first time this week.
The Nasdaq continued to lead with a 1.2% pop. But it climbed as much as 1.6% at session peak. The S&P 500 rose 0.5%, the Dow 0.4% and the NYSE composite 0.2%.
Volume was again tracking sharply higher across the board.
Aaron's (AAN) reversed early losses and gained 4% in active trading. The stock regained its 50-day moving average.
Baidu.com (BIDU) rose 3% after Goldman Sachs raised its price target to 350 from 300. The Chinese Internet search firm has tripled since its December low.
2:15 p.m. Update: Major Indexes Surge In Afternoon Trading
BY JONAH KERI
Stocks gained steam Wednesday, with the major indexes turning higher across the board.
The Nasdaq climbed 1.5%, the Dow and S&P 500 0.6% each and the NYSE composite 0.2%.
Volume swelled on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq.
Buckle (BKE) rose 3% in nearly twice its normal trade. The retail chain's stock is trying to rebound after starting a pullback in early May.
China-based online gaming firm Shanda Interactive Entertainment (SNDA) erased earlier losses, found support near its 50-day moving average and climbed 2%.
Also attempting to reclaim its former glory, Myriad Genetics (MYGN) gained 6%, propelling the gene therapy firm back above its 50-day line.
1:15 p.m. Update: Leading Stocks Rebound

5:15 p.m. Update:  The Nasdaq lost another skirmish with its 200-day moving average, but lower volume let the indexes avoid a distribution day.
Volume was about 1% lower on the Nasdaq and 11% down on NYSE. The Nasdaq closed below its 200-day line after three days above it. The area has served as resistance for more than a year.
Gold-mining stocks were among the strongest performers of the day. The metal ores group rose for a fourth-straight session.
The consumer electronics group was among the day's worst performers.
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Close Sharply Lower But Volume Falls
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
Stocks closed off session lows, but still with sharp losses.
The Nasdaq slid 1.9%, the S&P 500 1.8%, the Dow and NYSE composite 1.5%. But preliminary figures showed volume was lower, lessening the impact of the selling.
The Dow undercut its May low, while the other major indexes held above theirs. Despite a broad decline, relative few leading stocks fell in strong volume.
Steel, machinery, transportation and other industrials stocks fared worst in a broad decline.
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Scrape Intraday Lows In Slow Trade
BY PAUL WHITFIELD
Stocks scraped along intraday lows as volume remained off Wednesday's pace.
The Nasdaq led the retreat with a 2.8% dive. The S&P 500 and the Dow skidded 2.6% and 2.3%, respectively. The NYSE composite was down 2.4%.
The Philadelphia semiconductor index reeled 3.7%. Until today, it had risen for three straight sessions.
Volume was down 15% on the NYSE and 1% on the Nasdaq compared with the same time yesterday.
Losses were broad. Of IBD's 197 industry groups, only 10 were up. The winners included gold miners, computer data storage and career schools.
Two of those groups benefited from a single component that was up sharply.
In data storage, low-ranked Data Domain (DDUP) rocketed 34% to 24.03 in more than 12 times its usual trade on a takeover bid.
After Wednesday's close, NetApp (NTAP) announced that it would buy Data Domain for $25 a share.
NetApp rose 0.48 to 17.82 in more than triple its usual trade. It carries a mediocre Composite Rating of 77. Analysts have speculated that NetApp itself may be bought by Hewlett-Packard (HPQ).
Among career schools, Bridgepoint Education (BPI) jumped 28% in wild and huge trade. It reported a 116% increase in sales and a 163% pop in earnings. It launched its initial public offering April 15.
2:15 p.m. Update: Volume Dips, But Losses Expand
BY PAUL WHITFIELD
Stocks dug a deeper hole in afternoon trade, but volume dropped under Wednesday's pace.
If the slower trade continues, the indexes could duck a distribution day.
A distribution day is defined as a significant loss in heavier volume than the previous session. It points to institutional selling.
The Nasdaq was down 2.2%, slipping under its 200-day moving average. The S&P 500 was off 1.8% while the NYSE composite and the Dow fell 1.7%.
Volume was down 16% on the NYSE and 1% on the Nasdaq.
While more top-ranked stocks were falling than rising in fast trade, the gold-mining industry group was on track for a fourth consecutive gain.
The fundamentals in the group are patchy, but many of the stocks have either cleared bases or are near completing bases.
Only two stocks in the group have EPS Ratings of 94 or better; Yamana Gold (AUY) and Iamgold (IAG). Both recently cleared bases but are trading below $12 a share.
1:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Still Sag, But Volume Eases
BY PAUL WHITFIELD
Volume tailed off in midday trade as the indexes struggled to avoid another distribution day.
The Nasdaq was down 2.1%. The S&P 500 and the Dow trimmed 1.6%. The NYSE composite slid 1.4%.
Volume was up about 2% on the Nasdaq after being up as much as 12% earlier in the session. Trade on the NYSE was about 14% off Wednesday's pace.
Few top-ranked stocks were up in big trade.
One exception was Buckle (BKE). It rumbled 1.52 higher to 34.35 in double its routine trade. The teen-oriented retailer beat analysts' estimates but remains 22% off its 52-week high.
Far more top-ranked stocks were down in fast trade  not a good sign.

They included NewMarket (NEU), Advance Auto Parts (AAP), Universal Health Services (UHS), Cubic (CUB), Longtop Financial Technologies (LFT), Sociedad Quimica y Minera (SQM), Nustar Group Holdings (NSH), Concho Resources (CXO) and Quality Systems (QSII).
12:15 p.m. Update: Market Remains Sharply Lower At Midday
BY JONAH KERI
Stocks continued to struggle Thursday, as a decline in U.S. stocks followed the lead of foreign markets.
The Nasdaq sank 1.9%, while the Dow, S&P 500 and NYSE composite all fell 1.7%. The small-cap S&P 600 slipped 2%.
Volume was mixed. It eased 10% on the NYSE and swelled 6% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Wednesday.

Universal Health Services (UHS) slid 5% in more than three times its normal trade. The hospital operator tried to break out in September, failed, and has built a new base since then. The stock is now 21% off its 52-week high.
Several China-based stocks posted sizable losses.
Travel services company Ctrip.com (CTRP) skidded 4% in above-average volume. Financial software maker Longtop Financial Technologies (LFT) dived 9% and Yanzhou Coal Mining (YZC) slipped 4%.
Auto parts companies also dropped, as AutoZone (AZO) and Advance Auto Parts (AAP) both slid 2%.
11:15 a.m. Update: WEBHEAD: Stocks' Losses Accelerate
